title: When should you use the <article> element?
answers_1: For blog posts and other social media items
answers_2: When the content stands alone as a unit, is suitable for syndication, or is reusable
answers_3: For the main content area of your website
answers_4: To associate comments with a blog post
right_answer: When the content stands alone as a unit, is suitable for syndication, or is reusable

title: What is the difference between the <head> and <header> tags
answers_1: There is only one <head> tag per page, while there may be many <header> tags
answers_2: The <head> tag may contain CSS and Javascript links, while the <header> tag may contain headings and navigational links.
answers_3: The <head> tag contains meta information, while the <header> tag contains navigation, logos, and other page identifying content.

title: What is the difference between the <div> and <span> tags?
answers_1: <div> is used where a generic block-level tag is needed, while <span> is used where a generic inline tag is needed.
answers_2: <div> is used for major divisions on a page, while <span> is used to span across columns.
answers_3: <div> is the industry-standard default tag, but you could use <span> if you prefer.
answers_4: <div> is used where a generic inline tag is needed, while <span> is used where a generic block-level tag is needed.
right_answer: <div> is used where a generic block-level tag is needed, while <span> is used where a generic inline tag is needed.
